title: Perceptron Model
content:
The Perceptron, introduced by Frank Rosenblatt in 1957, is the simplest form of an artificial neural network. It's a binary linear classifier that can classify inputs into one of two categories.

It consists of a single layer of an artificial neuron (also known as a McCulloch-Pitts neuron). The perceptron takes multiple binary inputs, computes a weighted sum of these inputs, and then passes the sum through a step activation function to produce a binary output (0 or 1).

While revolutionary for its time, the single-layer perceptron has a significant limitation: it can only solve linearly separable problems. This means it cannot learn to classify data that cannot be separated by a single straight line, famously demonstrated by its inability to solve the XOR problem.
